contentData.text: We aim to make Sunday the best day of the week.

At St Philemon's, a church meeting is not about rules or rituals. It's all about relationships. That's why, whilst we're all obeying the government's guidance on social distancing, we meet together on Zoom. We need each other's help to live for Jesus and our time together helps equip us to worship in the coming week.

At St Philemon's, a church meeting is not about rules or rituals. It's all about relationships.

 

We meet together because we need one another's help to live for Jesus. And our time together on a Sunday helps equip us to worship him in the coming week. We use it to do the things the New Testament tells churches to do: things like ‘greet one another... honour one another... instruct one another... serve one another... encourage one another... carry each other’s burdens... pray for each other... confess your sins to each other... spur one another on towards love and good deeds’.

We keep things simple and informal. No-one has to say or do anything that might embarrass them.

 

Our first 25 minutes will be reasonably family-friendly because we cannot offer kids work in the usual way. Then we hope that children might survive in front of a telly for 30 minutes or something while we have the reading, message and some open prayer to close with.

 

We will see how it works and will welcome feedback!

We keep things simple and informal.

People wear anything from T-shirts to suits. No-one has to say or do anything that might embarrass them. You are welcome to bring kids of any age.

Services normally run for just over an hour, and here is how we spend that time (and why):

contentData.title: We share news
contentData.text:
A Christian community is like an extended family, with ages ranging from 0-100.

We love each other are keen to hear what's been happening in each other's lives, as well as celebrate birthdays etc.

contentData.title: We sing together
contentData.text: We love God and so we want to literally sing his praises. It is also a way for us to remind one another about his goodness and so encourage one another. So we sing a mixture of hymns and modern songs, at the start, the end and a few points in between. You are welcome to join in, whether you are an opera singer or completely tone deaf. Sometimes we sing more child-friendly songs, for which the actions are optional!

contentData.title: We confess our sins
contentData.text: The good news at the heart of Christianity is that God has done something through Jesus' death on the cross to enable us, even as sinful people, to be perfect in his sight. At St Philemon's we don't want to pretend to God or anyone else that we are better than we really are; at the same time, it is wonderful to hear afresh that there is no sin too shameful, no habit too ingrained and no situation too messy for God's grace not to cover it.

contentData.title: The Bible is read aloud and preached
contentData.text: This is how we listen to God. The sermon runs for about 25 minutes, and is intended to help us both to understand the reading and explain how it makes a difference to our lives.

contentData.title: The Bible is read aloud and preached
contentData.text: This is how we listen to God. The sermon runs for about 25 minutes, and is intended to help us both to understand the reading and explain how it makes a difference to our lives. Bibles are provided in English, Farsi and Kurdish and the page numbers are given.

contentData.title: We'll have Open Prayers
contentData.text: We'll be unmuted when it comes to when we have Open Prayers on Zoom. Anyone who wants to can lead the church family to pray. The rest of us will say 'Amen' if we want to make the prayer our own.

contentData.title: Someone leads us in prayer
contentData.text: Normally this is led by one or two people who stand at the front and pray aloud. The rest of us say 'Amen' if we want to make the prayer our own.

contentData.title: People might be baptised or we might share the Lord's Supper
contentData.text: We don't do these things every week - they are more like special celebrations. Baptism is a way of marking someone's start in the Christian life. The Lord's Supper is part of the way we press on in it. More about the Lord's Supper will be explained by the person leading the service, but it might help you to know that we take the bread and wine where we are sat, so it is easy for you to just pass the plate and cup along without any embarrassment.

contentData.title: We hear news from people
contentData.text:
(With their prior permission, of course!) It's great to hear how different people are doing during this time and to hear the honest stories of what God is up to in one another's lives. We can rejoice with those who are rejoicing, mourn with those who are mourning, and learn from one another.

 

We also make time to hear what people are up to that the rest of us might want to take part in.

contentData.title: We interview people
contentData.text: (With their prior permission, of course!) It's great to hear the honest stories of what God is up to in one another's lives, so that we can rejoice with those who are rejoicing, mourn with those who are mourning, and learn from one another. We also make time to hear what people are up to that the rest of us might want to take part in.

contentData.title: We end with tea, coffee and biscuits in the morning, and dinner in the evening
contentData.text: Of course, you can leave whenever you like. But most of us stick around for a fair while, just to be able to catch up more personally with people and perhaps talk about things that matter to us.

You don't need to believe anything in particular to come.

In fact, our services are a great way to find out more about Jesus and to consider what trust in him would look like. Our aim is to make that as easy and comfortable for you as possible.

A few times a year we meet all together as a church family for the whole of the service. It is noisy but wonderful! The rest of the time we run special groups for our children and young people up the the ages of 14. They leave us part way through the service and join us again at the end. They tend to look at the same section of the Bible as the adults (only in an age-appropriate way). This means that families can talk about what we are learning together. 

 

All our children’s leaders are trained and we rigorously follow the Church of England's best practice with respect to child protection. See here for more information on the specific groups, or if you want to contact the leader of your child's group.

If you come along, you may hear one person at the back of the building chatting away into a microphone. You will also notice a number of people listening to earphones. This is because at the 11am service we offer a translation service into Farsi and at the 5pm service we offer a translation service into Sorani Kurdish.

 

We hope it doesn't distract you too much. And if you think you'd prefer the service in Farsi or Sorani yourself, feel free to ask how you can get the in-ear translation!
